title: Workplace Bullying Prevention
legalBasis: Ley 31/1995 de Prevención de Riesgos Laborales (psychosocial risk prevention); Estatuto de los Trabajadores Article 4.2.e (right to dignity and respect); Criminal Code Article 173.1 (moral harassment); EU Framework Directive 89/391/EEC
summary:
Workplace bullying, known in Spanish as 'acoso laboral' or 'mobbing,' comprises repeated hostile behavior directed at a worker with the purpose or effect of degrading working conditions in ways that harm dignity, health, or professional future. It is distinct from occasional conflict, legitimate management action, or isolated incidents of rudeness, requiring instead a pattern of systematic mistreatment over time. Bullying creates profound harm to victims' psychological and physical health, professional development, and economic security. It also damages organizational performance through reduced productivity, elevated absenteeism and turnover, deteriorated team dynamics, and legal and reputational risks.

Spanish law addresses workplace bullying through multiple frameworks. Occupational health law (Ley 31/1995) classifies bullying as a psychosocial risk that employers must identify, assess, and control. Labor law (Estatuto de los Trabajadores) establishes the fundamental right to dignity and protection against degrading treatment in employment. In severe cases, workplace harassment can constitute a criminal offense under Article 173 of the Criminal Code. These legal frameworks create clear employer obligations to prevent bullying, respond promptly and effectively when it occurs, and provide remedies to affected workers.

The hospitality industry's hierarchical structures, high-pressure environments, and cultures that may normalize aggressive communication create particular bullying risks. Traditional kitchen hierarchies where chefs exert absolute authority can enable abusive behavior rationalized as 'tough leadership' or 'professional standards.' Service environments create pressures that may be displaced onto vulnerable workers. High staff turnover can obscure patterns of abuse as victims leave rather than complaining. Prevention requires cultural transformation, clear behavioral standards, training, monitoring, and consistent consequences for perpetrators regardless of their position or value to the organization.
keyPoints: Workplace bullying is repeated hostile behavior that degrades working conditions and harms dignity or wellbeing
Bullying is distinct from legitimate management actions, reasonable work demands, and isolated conflicts
Employers must identify, assess, and control bullying as part of psychosocial risk prevention obligations
Clear behavioral standards and anti-bullying policies must be established and communicated to all staff
Multiple reporting channels must be available, confidential, and free from retaliation
All reports must be investigated promptly, thoroughly, and impartially
Proven bullying warrants serious disciplinary action including potential dismissal
Victims must be supported and protected throughout the process and afterward
Prevention requires leadership commitment, cultural change, and accountability at all levels
Training on recognizing, preventing, and responding to bullying is essential for all staff

sections.heading: 1. Defining Workplace Bullying
sections.content:
Workplace bullying is characterized by repeated, systematic hostile behavior directed at one or more workers. The key elements are repetition (typically occurring over weeks or months rather than a single incident), hostile intent or hostile effect (regardless of whether harm was intended, the behavior creates a degrading environment), targeting of specific individuals (general workplace stress or conflict affecting everyone equally is not bullying), and power imbalance (the perpetrator has actual or perceived power over the target, whether through formal authority, expertise, social status, or group support).

Bullying behaviors take many forms. Verbal bullying includes insults, humiliation, constant criticism, belittling comments, shouting, and threats. Social bullying includes deliberate exclusion, ignoring or refusing to speak to the target, spreading rumors or damaging gossip, and undermining relationships with colleagues. Work-related bullying includes assigning impossible or meaningless tasks, removing responsibilities without justification, setting up to fail through inadequate resources or support, blocking training or advancement opportunities, and taking credit for the target's work. Physical intimidation, while less common, includes invading personal space, blocking movement, and physical threats or actual violence.

It is essential to distinguish bullying from legitimate management actions and normal workplace interactions. Setting performance expectations, providing constructive feedback, assigning work tasks, making scheduling decisions, and implementing disciplinary procedures are all legitimate management activities that are not bullying when conducted appropriately. The distinction lies in whether the actions are justified by business needs, proportionate, consistent with how others are treated, and conducted respectfully. Bullying often masquerades as management by being disproportionate, arbitrary, targeted, and conducted with hostility or intent to humiliate.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Common Bullying Scenarios in Hospitality
subsections.content:
In restaurant kitchens, bullying may involve chefs who use verbal abuse, thrown objects, or public humiliation as 'motivational' techniques, rationalizing this behavior as maintaining standards or teaching toughness. Senior staff may subject new or junior workers to hazing, excessive criticism, isolation, or sabotage under the guise of 'initiation' or 'paying dues.' Sous chefs or line cooks may target individuals they perceive as threats, weak, or different.

In front-of-house environments, bullying may involve supervisors who assign undesirable shifts as punishment, exclude certain staff from favorable sections or events, spread rumors about performance or personal life, or create arbitrary and changing standards that set certain employees up for failure. Peer bullying among service staff may involve cliques that exclude and undermine certain individuals, sabotaging their ability to perform well and earn tips. Managers may use their control over schedules and assignments as weapons to punish those they dislike or to coerce compliance.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Impact on Victims and Organizations
subsections.content:
Workplace bullying causes severe psychological harm including anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress symptoms, loss of confidence, sleep disturbances, and in extreme cases suicidal ideation. Physical health effects include stress-related conditions such as hypertension, headaches, gastrointestinal problems, and immune system suppression. Professional impacts include damaged reputation, blocked career progression, loss of income, and sometimes forced resignation or termination. The effects often persist long after the bullying ends.

Organizations pay substantial costs for bullying. Direct costs include absenteeism (bullying victims have significantly higher sick leave rates), turnover (both of victims who leave and bystanders who cannot tolerate the environment), and potential legal claims and settlements. Indirect costs include reduced productivity from the victim and from bystanders who are distracted or demoralized, damaged team cohesion, difficulty recruiting and retaining staff, and reputational harm that affects both employer brand and customer perception. Organizations that tolerate bullying lose their best people while retaining toxic individuals.

sections.heading: 2. Employer Obligations and Legal Framework
sections.content:
Spanish employers have comprehensive legal obligations regarding workplace bullying arising from multiple sources. Under Ley 31/1995 on occupational health, employers must identify, assess, and control all risks to worker health, including psychosocial risks such as workplace bullying. This requires conducting risk assessments that specifically consider bullying risk factors, implementing preventive measures, providing training, and monitoring effectiveness. The occupational health framework treats bullying as a preventable workplace hazard, not merely an interpersonal conflict that is outside employer control.

Under the Estatuto de los Trabajadores, employees have the fundamental right to respect for dignity and protection from verbal or physical offense. Employers must respect and protect this right. When bullying occurs, it constitutes a breach of the employer's duty to provide a safe, dignified work environment. Victims may have claims for breach of contract, constructive dismissal if forced to resign, or damages for harm suffered. Collective bargaining agreements in many sectors include additional specific provisions prohibiting workplace harassment and establishing procedures for addressing it.

In severe cases involving systematic psychological abuse, workplace bullying may constitute a criminal offense under Article 173.1 of the Criminal Code, which criminalizes 'moral harassment' in workplace, family, or institutional contexts. Criminal prosecution is independent of any civil or labor law proceedings and can result in imprisonment, fines, and prohibition from holding positions of authority. The threat of criminal liability underscores the severity with which Spanish law treats workplace bullying and creates personal accountability for perpetrators.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Vicarious Liability and Employer Responsibility
subsections.content:
Employers can be held liable for bullying committed by supervisors, managers, or even co-workers, under the doctrine of vicarious liability. The employer is responsible for providing a safe work environment and for the actions of those who act in the organization's name or with its authority. If an employer knew or should have known about bullying and failed to take adequate corrective action, liability is clear. Even if the employer was unaware of specific bullying incidents, liability may attach if the employer failed to implement adequate preventive measures (risk assessment, policies, training, reporting mechanisms).

This legal framework creates strong incentives for proactive prevention rather than reactive response. Employers cannot claim ignorance when they have failed to establish systems that would allow detection and reporting of bullying. The standard is not whether bullying occurred (which may be inevitable despite best efforts) but whether the employer took reasonable steps to prevent it and responded appropriately when it came to light.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Integration with Occupational Health System
subsections.content:
Anti-bullying measures must be integrated into the organization's overall occupational health and safety management system. The psychosocial risk assessment required under Ley 31/1995 must specifically evaluate bullying risk factors including: organizational culture and leadership styles, work organization and job demands, clarity of roles and expectations, levels of autonomy and control, fairness of treatment and decision-making, quality of interpersonal relationships, and mechanisms for conflict resolution. Based on this assessment, the Prevention Plan must include specific measures to control identified risks.

The occupational health service or external prevention service must be involved in bullying prevention and response. This may include: participating in risk assessment, providing expert input on policy development, training staff on bullying prevention, supporting investigations when bullying is alleged, providing or arranging psychological support for affected workers, and monitoring the effectiveness of preventive measures. Regular review and updating of the psychosocial risk assessment ensures that evolving risks are addressed.

sections.heading: 3. Prevention Through Culture and Policy
sections.content:
Effective bullying prevention begins with establishing a workplace culture of respect, dignity, and professionalism where bullying is understood to be unacceptable and incompatible with organizational values. This cultural foundation must be established through visible leadership commitment, clear behavioral standards, comprehensive training, and consistent modeling and enforcement. A formal anti-bullying policy codifies the organization's commitment and establishes specific procedures, but the policy alone is insufficient without the cultural substrate that gives it meaning and force.

The anti-bullying policy must clearly define prohibited conduct, provide examples relevant to the specific workplace context, establish multiple reporting channels, outline the investigation process, specify consequences for proven bullying, guarantee protection against retaliation, and commit to support for victims. The policy should be distributed to all employees during onboarding, posted in employee areas, referenced in employee handbooks, and reviewed periodically with all staff. It must be available in all languages spoken by the workforce to ensure accessibility.

Leadership commitment must be demonstrated through actions, not merely policy statements. Senior leaders must explicitly and repeatedly communicate that bullying will not be tolerated regardless of the perpetrator's position, performance, or tenure. They must model respectful behavior in their own interactions. Most critically, when bullying is substantiated, leadership must impose meaningful consequences even when the perpetrator is a high performer, has specialized skills, or has long tenure. Selective enforcement — protecting certain individuals while sanctioning others — destroys policy credibility and signals that bullying is actually tolerated when committed by valuable employees.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Behavioral Standards and Expectations
subsections.content:
Establish clear, specific behavioral standards that define what respectful professional conduct looks like in your specific context. Rather than vague exhortations to 'be respectful,' provide concrete guidance: 'We communicate professionally even under pressure, without shouting, insults, or personal attacks'; 'We provide performance feedback constructively and privately, focusing on specific behaviors rather than personal characteristics'; 'We disagree professionally about ideas without attacking the people who hold them'; 'We include all team members in relevant communications and decision-making.' These specific standards make expectations tangible and provide clear basis for addressing violations.

Address industry-specific behavioral patterns that may be normalized but are actually problematic. In kitchens, explicitly prohibit throwing objects, shouting abuse at staff, public humiliation, and use of degrading language even if these behaviors are portrayed as normal in culinary media or were experienced by current staff during their own training. In service environments, prohibit using schedule assignments or station allocations as punishment or reward unrelated to performance, excluding staff from meetings or information they need, and any form of retaliation for reporting concerns. Make clear that 'we've always done it this way' does not justify abusive behavior.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Training and Education
subsections.content:
Comprehensive training is essential for both prevention and early intervention. All employees should receive training covering: what workplace bullying is and what it is not, why it is harmful to individuals and organizations, examples of bullying behaviors specific to hospitality contexts, how to recognize warning signs in yourself and others, how to respond if you witness bullying, how to report bullying, and what to expect if you report. Training should be interactive, using scenarios and discussions rather than lecture, and should create psychological safety for participants to share concerns and questions.

Managers and supervisors require specialized additional training on: their role in prevention through modeling and culture-setting, how to provide performance feedback and discipline without crossing into bullying, how to recognize and address bullying among staff they supervise, how to receive and respond to complaints, their legal obligations and potential personal liability, and the importance of taking reports seriously and not dismissing them as 'personality conflicts' or 'people being too sensitive.' Manager training should include skill-building in difficult conversations, conflict resolution, and fair, consistent decision-making.

sections.heading: 4. Reporting, Investigation, and Response
sections.content:
A well-designed reporting system provides multiple accessible pathways for victims and witnesses to bring forward concerns, ensures confidentiality to the extent possible, protects against retaliation, and commits to prompt, thorough investigation and appropriate action. Many bullying situations go unreported because victims fear they will not be believed, that reporting will make the situation worse, that nothing will be done, or that they will face retaliation. Building a trustworthy reporting system requires addressing each of these concerns through system design and demonstrated track record.

Reporting options should include: direct report to immediate supervisor (if they are not the alleged perpetrator), report to human resources or designated bullying officer, report to any member of senior management, report to worker representatives or union officials, anonymous hotline or web-based reporting system, and external resources such as occupational health services. Multiple pathways ensure that reporters can choose an avenue with which they feel comfortable. For small establishments without dedicated HR, designate a specific person as contact or establish relationship with external consultant or legal advisor who can receive reports.

When a report is received, the immediate priorities are: ensuring the safety and wellbeing of the complainant, acknowledging the report and thanking the person for coming forward, explaining the investigation process and approximate timeline, implementing any immediate protective measures needed (such as schedule changes to reduce contact, temporary supervision modifications, or in serious cases temporary leave for one party), reminding about anti-retaliation protections, and assigning an impartial investigator. All these steps should occur within 24-48 hours of receiving the report.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Investigation Process and Methodology
subsections.content:
The investigation must be prompt (generally completed within 2-4 weeks), thorough, and impartial. The investigator must be neutral — not close to either party, not someone with vested interest in a particular outcome, and ideally someone with specific training in workplace investigations. For small organizations, this often requires external investigator. The process includes: reviewing any written complaint and supporting materials, interviewing the complainant in detail, interviewing the alleged perpetrator, interviewing relevant witnesses identified by either party, reviewing any documentary evidence (emails, messages, performance records, schedule assignments, prior complaints), assessing credibility of all parties, and making findings based on balance of evidence.

Bullying investigations present particular challenges because direct evidence is often limited. Bullying typically occurs without independent witnesses, evidence may be ambiguous (was that email sarcastic or professional? was that task assignment inappropriate or merely difficult?), and the pattern nature of bullying means that no single incident may appear serious in isolation. Investigators must consider: consistency of accounts, specificity and detail in descriptions, whether there is a pattern of similar behavior, whether witnesses corroborate the hostile environment even if they didn't see specific incidents, whether the accused's behavior toward the complainant differs from behavior toward others, and whether the accused has history of similar complaints. The standard is balance of probabilities — is it more likely than not that bullying occurred?

subsections.heading: 4.2 Consequences and Remedies
subsections.content:
When investigation substantiates bullying, consequences must be serious, proportionate to severity, and consistent with how similar cases have been handled. For moderate cases involving hostile behavior without severe impact or aggravating factors, sanctions might include mandatory training, formal written warning, temporary suspension, or demotion. For serious cases involving prolonged systematic harassment, abuse of authority, severe impact on victim, or patterns across multiple victims, dismissal is often appropriate. Spanish labor law provides for dismissal for 'serious and culpable breach' of duties, and substantiated workplace bullying clearly meets this standard.

Remedies for the victim should include: formal acknowledgment that the bullying occurred and should not have happened, opportunity to remain in role or transfer to different area depending on preference, access to psychological counseling or support at employer expense, compensation for any economic losses, restoration of any opportunities denied due to bullying, and ongoing monitoring for retaliation. Organizational corrective actions should address any systemic factors that enabled or contributed to the bullying: supervisory training, policy reinforcement, cultural interventions, restructuring reporting relationships if necessary, and enhanced monitoring of the area where bullying occurred.

sections.heading: 5. Supporting Victims and Preventing Retaliation
sections.content:
Victims of workplace bullying require active support throughout the reporting and investigation process and beyond. The experience of being bullied is itself harmful and often involves feelings of powerlessness, self-doubt, and fear. The process of reporting and being involved in an investigation can feel re-victimizing if not handled sensitively. Organizations must ensure that victims feel supported, believed, and protected, and that the process does not cause additional harm.

Immediate support measures include: expressing that the report is taken seriously, ensuring immediate physical safety if there are concerns about confrontation or retaliation, providing information about available resources (counseling, employee assistance programs, external support organizations), maintaining regular communication about the investigation process and timeline, and implementing protective measures such as schedule adjustments or reporting relationship changes if needed. Throughout the process, maintain appropriate confidentiality while keeping the victim informed about general progress without violating the procedural fairness owed to the accused.

Retaliation protection is critical because fear of retaliation is the primary reason bullying goes unreported. Retaliation can take many forms: termination or demotion, changes to work assignments or schedule, exclusion from communications or opportunities, increased scrutiny or criticism, or creation of hostile environment by colleagues who support the accused. All of these are prohibited, and the anti-bullying policy must explicitly state that retaliation is independently sanctionable even if the underlying bullying complaint is not substantiated. Managers must understand that any adverse action toward a complainant will be scrutinized intensely and must be supported by clear, documented, pre-existing justification.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Psychological Support and Recovery
subsections.content:
Workplace bullying can cause serious psychological harm that requires professional support. Organizations should provide or facilitate access to psychological counseling for bullying victims at no cost to the employee. This might be through an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) if available, through the occupational health service, or by directly engaging external mental health professionals. The support should be confidential and should continue for as long as needed, which may be months beyond the resolution of the immediate situation.

Recognize that recovery from bullying takes time and that victims may need workplace accommodations during this period. This might include temporary reduction in workload, flexibility in schedule, transfer to different work area away from reminders of the bullying, and patience with performance as the individual recovers. Frame these accommodations as the organization taking responsibility for harm that occurred in its workplace, not as special favors to the victim. Create a supportive return-to-work process if the victim took leave, ensuring they are reintegrated smoothly without stigma.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Monitoring and Long-Term Follow-Up
subsections.content:
After resolution of a bullying case, continue monitoring for at least 6-12 months to ensure retaliation does not occur and that the victim is recovering. This monitoring includes: regular check-ins with the victim asking specifically about any retaliation or continuing problems, review of any employment actions affecting the victim to ensure they are justified and not retaliatory, interviews with colleagues to assess whether work environment has improved, and investigation of any concerns that arise. Document all monitoring activities.

If the perpetrator remains employed (for example, if they received discipline short of dismissal), monitor their behavior to ensure there is no continuing problematic conduct toward the victim or others. This might include: periodic check-ins with their supervisor about conduct, requiring regular progress reports on any corrective actions (training, counseling), and interviews with colleagues to assess whether behavior has improved. If problematic behavior continues, escalate sanctions up to and including dismissal. Second chances are appropriate in some cases, but only when accompanied by genuine change.

sections.heading: 6. Creating Sustainable Cultural Change
sections.content:
Addressing workplace bullying ultimately requires cultural transformation, not merely policy implementation. Culture encompasses the shared values, beliefs, and behavioral norms that govern how people interact. In toxic cultures, bullying is normalized, rationalized, or minimized. In healthy cultures, bullying is recognized as unacceptable and incompatible with organizational identity. Cultural change is slow and requires sustained effort, leadership commitment, and willingness to address difficult truths about current state.

Begin by acknowledging current reality honestly. If bullying has been tolerated or ignored historically, admit this openly and commit to change. Denial or minimization destroys credibility. Senior leadership should communicate clearly: 'We have not always lived up to our values in how people are treated here. We know that bullying has occurred and has harmed our people. This is unacceptable and it changes now.' This honest acknowledgment creates psychological safety for people to report problems and believe they will be addressed.

Cultural change requires changing systems, not just individual behaviors. Systems include: how people are recruited and what qualities are valued in selection, how performance is evaluated and whether respectful conduct is weighted equally with task performance, how people are promoted and whether abusive managers advance or are held back, how conflicts are resolved and whether abuse is rationalized or addressed, what behaviors are celebrated and recognized, and what behaviors are sanctioned. When systems consistently reinforce respect and consistently sanction abuse, culture changes. When systems are inconsistent — punishing some bullies while promoting others — culture remains toxic.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Leadership Accountability and Modeling
subsections.content:
Leaders must model the respectful behavior expected of all staff. This is particularly challenging in high-pressure hospitality environments where stress is constant and tempers may flare. Leaders must demonstrate that professionalism can be maintained even under pressure, that accountability can be enforced without humiliation, and that high standards can be upheld through constructive feedback rather than abuse. When leaders fail to model expected behavior — shouting at staff, making demeaning comments, treating people disrespectfully — they signal that the anti-bullying policy is mere rhetoric.

Leaders must be held accountable for creating respectful environments in their areas of responsibility. Include behavioral expectations in management performance evaluations and weight them heavily. A manager who achieves operational goals through abusive behavior is not a successful manager and should not be rewarded. Conversely, recognize and reward managers who build high-performing teams through respectful leadership. Promote from within based partly on how candidates treat colleagues, not solely on technical skills or results achieved through any means.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Continuous Improvement and Monitoring
subsections.content:
Assess workplace culture regularly through employee surveys that ask specifically about bullying experiences, perceptions of organizational response, and whether employees believe reporting would be effective and safe. Anonymous surveys provide valuable data about prevalence and about areas where prevention efforts need strengthening. Complement quantitative surveys with qualitative methods such as focus groups or exit interviews that explore experiences in depth.

Use this data to drive continuous improvement. If surveys reveal that certain departments or shifts have higher bullying prevalence, target prevention efforts there. If employees report low confidence in reporting mechanisms, investigate why and strengthen those systems. If certain types of bullying are more common, address them through specific training or policy emphasis. Make results transparent to the workforce, sharing overall findings (while protecting confidentiality) and the action plan to address identified issues. This transparency builds trust and demonstrates that the organization takes feedback seriously.

checklists.title: Anti-Bullying Policy Implementation Checklist
items: Written anti-bullying policy adopted defining prohibited conduct and procedures
Policy communicated to all employees and posted in employee areas
Multiple reporting channels established and clearly communicated
Designated person or department identified to receive and coordinate response to reports
All employees trained on recognizing, preventing, and reporting bullying
Managers trained on prevention, investigation, and response responsibilities
Policy integrated into occupational health psychosocial risk assessment
Confidential complaint and investigation procedures established
Anti-retaliation protections clearly communicated and enforced
Procedures for supporting victims during and after investigation established
Disciplinary framework for substantiated bullying established
Regular monitoring and review processes established

checklists.title: Bullying Report Response Checklist
items: Report received and documented with date, time, and reporter information
Reporter thanked for coming forward and assured report is taken seriously
Immediate safety needs assessed and protective measures implemented if needed
Investigation process explained including approximate timeline
Anti-retaliation protections explained and contact provided for reporting any retaliation
Impartial investigator assigned who is trained and has no conflict of interest
Complainant interviewed in detail to gather all relevant information
Alleged perpetrator interviewed and given opportunity to respond
Relevant witnesses identified and interviewed
Documentary evidence reviewed (emails, performance records, etc.)
Findings made based on balance of evidence
Appropriate consequences implemented if bullying substantiated
Victim provided with remedies and ongoing support
Organizational corrective actions implemented to prevent recurrence
Monitoring plan established to ensure no retaliation and assess recovery

checklists.title: Workplace Culture Assessment Checklist
items: Anonymous employee survey conducted asking about bullying experiences and perceptions
Survey results analyzed overall and by department/shift/role
Exit interviews reviewed for any patterns of bullying-related departures
Complaint and incident data reviewed to identify any trends
Focus groups or listening sessions conducted to understand culture in depth
Management practices observed to assess whether they align with stated values
Promotion and reward patterns analyzed to see whether respectful behavior is valued
Training effectiveness assessed through participant feedback and behavioral observation
Findings shared with leadership and worker representatives
Action plan developed to address identified cultural issues
Progress against action plan monitored and communicated
Culture assessment repeated annually to track changes over time

bestPractices: Address low-level disrespect immediately before it escalates to bullying — maintain clear behavioral boundaries from the start
Frame anti-bullying efforts positively as creating a respectful, professional culture rather than negatively as preventing bad behavior
Ensure that high-performing staff are held to the same behavioral standards as everyone else — skill does not excuse abuse
Provide coaching and support to managers on how to hold people accountable respectfully — performance management without humiliation
Create forums for constructive conflict resolution so that normal workplace disagreements don't escalate into hostile relationships
Celebrate and recognize teams and leaders who exemplify respectful, high-performing cultures
Be transparent about the organization's commitment and track record — share aggregated data on reports received and actions taken
Engage external experts for particularly complex cases or to provide fresh perspective on cultural issues
Recognize that addressing bullying may be uncomfortable and generate resistance — stay committed through the difficult conversations
Remember that organizational tolerance for bullying loses your best people while protecting your worst — making change is worth the effort

glossary.Workplace Bullying: Repeated hostile behavior directed at a worker with the purpose or effect of degrading working conditions and harming dignity, health, or professional development
glossary.Mobbing: The Spanish term for workplace psychological harassment or bullying, derived from animal behavior research on group attacks
glossary.Psychosocial Risk: Workplace conditions related to work organization, content, or social relations that can harm psychological or physical health
glossary.Vicarious Liability: Legal responsibility of employers for harmful acts committed by employees in the course of their employment
glossary.Constructive Dismissal: When working conditions become so intolerable that the employee is forced to resign, treated legally as if the employer terminated the employment
glossary.Balance of Probabilities: The standard of proof in civil matters and workplace investigations — whether it is more likely than not that the alleged conduct occurred
glossary.Impartial Investigator: A person conducting an investigation who has no conflict of interest, no close relationship with parties, and no vested interest in particular outcome
glossary.Retaliation: Adverse action taken against a person because they reported bullying, participated in investigation, or opposed bullying behavior
glossary.Protective Measures: Actions taken during investigation to ensure victim safety and prevent retaliation, such as schedule adjustments or reporting relationship changes
glossary.Cultural Transformation: Fundamental change in shared values, beliefs, and behavioral norms within an organization, required for sustainable bullying prevention
